<panel  header="**86 :octicon-git-pull-request::octicon-comment:** (commented on others PR)" popup-url="https://github.com/AY2223S2-CS2113-T12-4/tp/pull/33#discussion_r1131966756" expanded>

Thank you for the notification.

Yes, I propose breaking `help` into 4 parts: the feature keyword(e.g. `hb`), a `String` of the entire list of supported commands, a brief description of the feature, and a detailed description of the feature.

I propose delegating the 4 parts this way: feature keyword is stored in the feature's `Manager`(exposed with a getter), `String` of all subcommands is also stored in the feature's `Manager`(also exposed with a getter), brief description of the feature is also stored in the corresponding `Manager`. The complicated part, and the part that warrants the most discussion is I believe the detailed description. This is my rough concept for it:

-`Manager` will have a detailed _overall_ description of the feature, such as `Atomic habits: Inspired by the book ..., this feature allows you to propose and keep track of atomic habits you desire to develop in the hopes that it may improve your lifestyle.` for the atomic habits feature
-Every `Command` of a feature will provide(via getters, one each):
1. `String` of all the arguments for that specific `Command`
2. Detailed description of the command(what it does, any default behaviour when optional arguments are omitted, etc)
-`Manager` will provide a getter for a detailed description of the entire feature's commands. This is essentially just iterating through all of the `Command`s and calling their argument getter and detailed description getter
-`HelpCommand`'s job is to standardise the format of the brief description and detailed descriptions, and iterate through all the `Manager`s when printing the detailed description(via each `Manager`'s getter), and print the output using `TextUi`
-`HelpCommand` **will not** know about what commands/features are supported by `WellNus` or what description they have, this will be delegated to helper methods provided by `Manager`s for encapsulation and to aid maintainability so that individual feature developers will decide how they want to describe their features and commands

What are your thoughts @YongbinWang @nichyjt ?
</panel>

<panel  header="**348 :octicon-git-pull-request::octicon-comment:** (commented on own PR)" popup-url="https://github.com/AY2223S2-CS2113-T12-4/tp/pull/265#discussion_r1158704137" expanded>

Aha, this particular edge case is actually caught in `GamificationStorage` line 33. No exception will be thrown if data file doesn't exist. My intention is to _not_ create the gamif data file if no data is saved(i.e. no XP points updated during the app run), since any XP update will trigger a `Storage.saveData()` call that creates the gamif data file if it doesn't already exist.

Basically lazy initialisation of the data file to reduce unnecessary I/O.

Tested this to ensure that no exceptions occur in 4 cases:
1. gamif data file doesn't exist, XP updated: Stats is restored successfully on the next run of the app
2. gamif data file exists, XP updated: stats is updated and restored successfully the next run of the app
3. gamif data file doesn't exist, XP not updated: stats is the default value, no exceptions thrown, stats is still the default value on the next run of the app
4. gamif data file exists, XP not updated: stats is restored successfully
</panel>

<panel  header="**352 :octicon-comment:** (other comment)" popup-url="https://github.com/AY2223S2-CS2113-T12-4/tp/issues/22#issuecomment-1462112627" expanded>

Some suggested shared behavior(and their functionality) for `Managers`(to put in the abstract superclass):
-getFeatureKeyword(): Returns the command keyword, e.g. hb, timer
-getArgumentsForFeatureDescription(): Returns the full list of arguments supported by the feature, e.g. add [--name] &gt;name> for hb
-getBriefDescriptionOfFeature(): Returns a brief description of this feature to be printed by the basic help command
-getFullDescriptionOfFeature(): Returns a full description for the corresponding specialised help command of this feature, e.g. help hb for hb
-isValidCommand(): Accepts a HashMap of commandline arguments and returns a boolean for whether they represent valid input for this Command
-goToFeature(): Brings user to the specific feature's user interface, where feature-specific commands are then available. Expectation is goToFeature() will exit and return to its parent event driver when user elects to exit the feature
</panel>

<panel  header="**1 :octicon-git-pull-request::octicon-comment:** (commented on others PR)" popup-url="https://github.com/AY2223S2-CS2113-T12-4/tp/pull/25#discussion_r1130795354" expanded>

Is UI supposed to be extended on by each feature?

By declaring different formats by each feature from the get-go, we are going to introduce tight coupling across many features.

This might cause many merge conflicts and regression issues down the line as our project grows.

Do you think it makes sense if we have a single SEPARATOR variable or method that can be overridden? 
</panel>

<panel  header="**2 :octicon-git-pull-request::octicon-comment:** (commented on others PR)" popup-url="https://github.com/AY2223S2-CS2113-T12-4/tp/pull/25#discussion_r1130812417" expanded>

I think that we may face scaling & human error issues if we approach labelling features this way. 

 Labelling by character may be confusing to the developer.

Perhaps we can consider using an `Enum`.
Along the lines of:
```java
enum Features {
    MAIN,
    ATOMIC,
    REFLECT
}
```
Why I'm suggesting this is because this is because this syntatic sugar will allow us to know **exactly** what we are dealing with.

When we process features, using enum would loosely look like:
```java
if(feature == Feature.MAIN) { ... }
else if(feature == Feature.ATOMIC) { ... }
else if(feature == Feature.REFLECT) { ... }
```
I feel that this is more easy to read (as developers) and allows us to make less errors rather than
```java
if(feature ==  'm') { ... }
else if(feature == 'a') { ... }
else if(feature == 'r') { ... }
```

In terms of scaling, all we need to do is add an entry on the enum file. 

What do you think?
</panel>

<panel  header="**104 :octicon-git-pull-request::octicon-comment:** (commented on others PR)" popup-url="https://github.com/AY2223S2-CS2113-T12-4/tp/pull/155#discussion_r1144683078" expanded>

It seems like there is some on-demand base-60 conversion going on to calculate minutes and seconds. This feels very *verilog-y* 

I think that moving forward, this might be harder to debug, especially when debugging edge cases such as sending commands when `seconds == DEFAULT_STOP_TIME`.

You can ignore this comment for now, but here is my two cents regarding maintainability and readability for time:

Can I ask what is the benefit of maintaining the extra logic and constants to handle this base-60 logic?

Could simply storing the number of `seconds` be sufficient?

To get the minutes and seconds, one just needs to call a function that does:
```java
int minutes = seconds/60;
int secondsLeft = seconds%60;
```
This may be much more readable & maintainable than calculating the minutes and time per-tick. We get rid of constants which may help us developers reduce some cognitive load.

Performance wise, we also avoid potential pitfalls if the timer task's `run()` is run concurrently to an input command (something like a [race condition](https://www.techtarget.com/searchstorage/definition/race-condition)).  

Reducing the if-else block (thereby improving performance of the time-sensitive `run()` block may reduce the execution time of that block and reduce the probability of race conditions happening. (This is a very minor issue though, as I believe java would properly handle concurrency in their Timer task).

Edit: Code correctness
</panel>

<panel  header="**141 :octicon-git-pull-request::octicon-comment:** (commented on own PR)" popup-url="https://github.com/AY2223S2-CS2113-T12-4/tp/pull/19#discussion_r1130328599" expanded>

<panel  header="**142 :octicon-git-pull-request::octicon-comment:** (commented on own PR)" popup-url="https://github.com/AY2223S2-CS2113-T12-4/tp/pull/19#discussion_r1130346878" expanded>

Oh! This is actually defined behaviour.  

In this case, payload1 is accepted as an argument (key value).  

CommandParser's job is to screen for syntactically wrong inputs only. Setting payload as argument is a logical error on the users' part.   

As we discussed, the responsibility of logic-based checks like type-checking and length-checking is up to each feature using CommandParser to avoid tightly coupling the Parser to each feature.

This also follows the [Single Responsibility Principle](https://nus-cs2113-ay2223s2.github.io/website/se-book-adapted/common/definitions.html#s).   

A benefit of the hashmap architecture is that we can effectively ignore bad inputs like these.  
We can just `.get` the keys we expect to have.

If we want to be super strict, on the feature level, once an unknown key is encountered, the feature can just throw a custom `InvalidArgument` exception or handle the error along those lines. 

I don't see a way to differentiate arguments from payloads without each feature's parsing logic being tightly coupled with each feature's unique requirements. What are your thoughts?
</panel>

<panel  header="**153 :octicon-git-pull-request::octicon-comment:** (commented on own PR)" popup-url="https://github.com/AY2223S2-CS2113-T12-4/tp/pull/169#discussion_r1148902153" expanded>

<panel  header="**154 :octicon-git-pull-request::octicon-comment:** (commented on own PR)" popup-url="https://github.com/AY2223S2-CS2113-T12-4/tp/pull/169#discussion_r1148919284" expanded>

Yes, this will set the current countdown index to the last index.

I'll explain the thought process here for documentation sake and for you to check if it makes sense!

This behaviour due to your initial implementation of the code where increments will only occur on `start` and `next`.

To have this logic work without excessive use of flags and passing messages between components, I thought that the common behaviour for `start`ing a session the 1st time and nth time would naturally be to have the pointer at the last countdown with the `isReadyFlag`. 

The idea is that when a session ends, the `currentCountdownIndex` pointer will always point to the last countdown object. Since increments are only done in `start` and `next` commands as per your implementation, I need a way to differentiate between the two using the `isReady` flag. 

To make this behaviour invariant,the  `stop` command also forces `currentCountdownIndex` to point to the last countdown object and toggle its `isReady` flag to true.

```java
// starting from StopCommand line 81
session.getCurrentCountdown().setStop();
sessioninitialiseSession();
session.resetCurrentCountdownIndex();
```

I have experimented with making the timer 1-indexed and even having the flag on , but without massive workarounds to have flags being passed between `Countdown` and `Session`, it is unfeasible. I felt that it would be much better to work with the code you have implemented already since it works!  
</panel>

<panel  header="**171 :octicon-comment:** (other comment)" popup-url="https://github.com/AY2223S2-CS2113-T12-4/tp/issues/85#issuecomment-1471569085" expanded>

Thanks @haoyangw for the detailed writeup and post-mortem analysis of the crash. This is an excellent learning point for the whole team. 
 
Haoyang, I agree with the proposed changes for SelfReflection. The benefits make sense and I've actually mentioned these in my PR reviews before. For reference:
- https://github.com/AY2223S2-CS2113-T12-4/tp/pull/35#discussion_r1133057443 &gt;- buggy behaviour
- https://github.com/AY2223S2-CS2113-T12-4/tp/pull/27#discussion_r1131179789 &gt;- extensibility

To prevent this from happening again, as rule of thumb:
`static final` and `static` should be reserved **only** for constants. Refer to https://github.com/AY2223S2-CS2113-T12-4/tp/pull/31#discussion_r1131876665

By constants, I mean magic literals that have only one state (its literal value).

From now on, I propose that this should be much more strictly checked during PRs.

To add on to the discussion, I think the whole intent behind the agreed upon architecture through the `Command` and `Manager` boilerplate is to **instantiate** all variables that have **state** within the constructor. This is enforced through the `abstract` methods. This should have made integration much less difficult and more standardized. 

Let's be more careful with the way we use the `static` keyword from here onwards.

What do the others think?
</panel>

Yes I agree with the rationale behind avoiding using static. 

What I did to fix ```SelfReflection``` is to change all the methods and attributes(except constants) to non-static, so that every time when an object is created, a new array of 5 questions will be created. <panel  header="**30 :octicon-git-pull-request::octicon-comment:** (commented on others PR)" popup-url="https://github.com/AY2223S2-CS2113-F10-1/tp/pull/153#discussion_r1155236602" expanded>

I think this is more confusing than having the Options being built in each XYZKeywordParser -- since our command looks like `&gt;keyword> &gt;action> flags`, once we parse the action we shouldn't need to look at the keyword anymore (so a more hierachial design).

If you wanted to go by the OOP route, perhaps something like this would be neater:
- Since `OptionsBuilder` does not really have a state (i.e., `model` and `action` are only used once, then a new `OptionsBuilder` is created the next time), maybe you could just do `static buildOptions(String keyword, String action)`
- Have an abstract `KeywordOptionBuilder`, which `XYZKeywordOptionBuilder` extends
- Move all the option building (e.g., `buildDeleteOptions`) to `XYZKeywordOptionBuilder`. `XYZKeywordOptionBuilder` will have a switch-case on how to handle each **action**
- `KeywordOptionBuilder.buildOptions` has a switch-case to handle each **keyword** and call the appropriate `XYZKeywordOptionBuilder.buildOption()`
- Functions that are used by multiple `XYZKeywordOptionBuilder` can be protected static functions in the abstract `KeywordOptionBuilder` (e.g., `buildCardSelectOption`)

This design is parallel to how `KeywordParser` and `XYZKeywordParser` are currently designed.
</panel>

If the commands are just capital letter and the dashes are replaced with underscore, do considering implementing it in such a manner:

```java
public enum CommandType {
    EXIT, SHOW_RATE;
}
```
## String to Enum
```java
String command = args[0].replaceAll("-", "_").toUpperCase();
CommandType type = CommandType.valueOf(command);
```
By default, the second line should already throw an error if no such enum value is found. Example can be found in the other file with the ShowRate class. You can create an utility class with generics for future enums.

## Enum To String
```java
String command = CommandType.EXIT.name().replace("_", "-").toLowerCase();
```
## Alternative
Alternatively, just use an interface.
</panel>

<panel  header="**58 :octicon-comment:** (other comment)" popup-url="https://github.com/AY2223S2-CS2113-W15-2/tp/issues/194#issuecomment-1499923550" expanded>

This issue is highly opinionated and will not be considered as a bug for the application.

As highlighted in the [`SimpleDateFormat` API](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/text/SimpleDateFormat.html), 
> For parsing with the abbreviated year pattern ("y" or "yy"), SimpleDateFormat must interpret the abbreviated year relative to some century. It does this by adjusting dates to be within 80 years before and 20 years after the time the SimpleDateFormat instance is created.

the following command would result in an error since it is ambiguous:
`/view -sd 01/01/43 -ed 31/12/19`

As such, it would be good to highlight this behaviour to the user in the user guide.
</panel>

<panel  header="**32 :octicon-git-pull-request::octicon-comment:** (commented on own PR)" popup-url="https://github.com/AY2223S2-CS2113-T13-1/tp/pull/195#discussion_r1161121763" expanded>

Thank you for bringing up the point on non-numeric values! After some consideration, I have decided not to use the Validator here for 2 reasons. 
1. I need to implement custom logic for both potential errors, either setting the balance to 10 million if it is too large or 0 if it is negative. The validator throws the same exception with different error messages, and working around it would probably lead to some janky logic. 
2. The gson parser already handles the potential non-numeric cases by throwing a parse error. We currently handle that by wiping the file as it is deemed an "irrecoverable" error. We also avoid precision errors as we store the balances as integers instead of floats, so it cannot be edited to have more than 3 decimal places. 
</panel>

Instead of repeating code here, you can nest the `hasQuantity`  if-block inside this block and make use of short-circuiting.

For example:
```
name = foodInfo[0];
date = foodInfo[1];

if(hasQuantity) {
    quantity = foodInfo[2];
    String[] foodDetails = {name, date, quantity};
    return foodDetails;
}

String[] foodDetails = {name, date};
return foodDetails;
```
</panel>

<panel  header="**29 :octicon-comment:** (other comment)" popup-url="https://github.com/AY2223S2-CS2113T-T09-1/tp/pull/339#issuecomment-1493222909" expanded>

For line 30-39 of command class, the checks is to ensure that the name of the shortcut does not overlap with an actual command like `view`. So a command such as `shortcut view -maps add -out noodles $5` will be prevented. This is because previously the actual `view` command will take priority over the configured shortcut `view` command, and to prevent any confusion we can stop the user from creating such a shortcut.

I think we should not restrict users to creating shortcuts for just add and filter, as there could be other legitimate uses like `shortcut v -maps view` etc. The suggestion of only allowing valid commands to be mapped can be a future feature consideration, but for now, the short-term fix is that the terminal will print the shortcut that the user is currently using and the actual command executed so that the user can be aware if their shortcut command is invalid, as they are using it.
</panel>

if the args here is not a valid integer, then `Integer.parseInt(args)` will already throw a NumberFormatException. So I think it might be good to consider how to refactor this without the try and catch in the else.

```
        if (size == 0) {
            throw new NoTransactionsFoundException();
        }
        try {
            int index = Integer.parseInt(args) - 1;
            if (index > size || index < 1) {
                throw new IndexOutOfBoundsException();
            }
            transactions.remove(index);
            size--;
            ui.showTransactionDeletedMessage();
        } catch (NumberFormatException e) {
            throw new NumberFormatException();
        } catch (IndexOutOfBoundsException e) {
            throw new IndexOutOfBoundsException();
        } catch (Exception e) {
            e.printStackTrace();
        }
```

I think something like the above might be a better way to refactor.

<panel  header="**1 :octicon-git-pull-request::octicon-comment:** (commented on others PR)" popup-url="https://github.com/AY2223S2-CS2113-F10-4/tp/pull/8#discussion_r1127493185" expanded>

A minor issue: it is redundant to write `public` and `abstract` for methods in an interface. From [Oracle Java Documentation](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/specs/jls/se7/html/jls-9.html#jls-9.4):  

> It is permitted, but discouraged as a matter of style, to redundantly specify the public and/or abstract modifier for a method declared in an interface.

You can directly write:
``` java
public interface IBlahBlah {
    int foo();
    void bar();
}

```
</panel>

<panel  header="**4 :octicon-comment:** (other comment)" popup-url="https://github.com/AY2223S2-CS2113-W13-1/tp/issues/153#issuecomment-1493252234" expanded>

The intention behind it would be to inform the user what exactly is he entering into Dr Duke. This example here accounts for the case where the user enters the same "s" consecutively. But for cases where the "s" might not be entered consecutively, for example "absefsgts", 3 s's are entered but not one after the other, so showing 3 error messages would let the user know he "accidentally" entered the same symptom 3 times.
</panel>

<panel  header="**5 :octicon-comment:** (other comment)" popup-url="https://github.com/AY2223S2-CS2113-W13-1/tp/issues/149#issuecomment-1493252504" expanded>

We treat this single user to be a single kind of user, where only patients are intended to access this program.

The multiple accounts, while yes they mean multiple users, are all only for patients, thus is still in line with "single user".
</panel>

<panel  header="**6 :octicon-comment:** (other comment)" popup-url="https://github.com/AY2223S2-CS2113-W13-1/tp/issues/136#issuecomment-1493252982" expanded>

Entering more than 24 symptoms is not actually entering more than 24 symptoms, but rather entering "duplicate" symptoms, thus giving the impression of a user inputting more than 24 symptoms.

We give the user freedom of choice to enter whatever symptoms he/she has, but we inform them if they have entered duplicate symptoms.
</panel>

<panel  header="**7 :octicon-comment:** (other comment)" popup-url="https://github.com/AY2223S2-CS2113-W13-1/tp/issues/144#issuecomment-1493255109" expanded>

This ties in to the user experience of the program. We require the user to input his name into Dr Duke, so that Dr Duke knows how to address the user, making the program feel more personal, improving user experience.
</panel>

<panel  header="**8 :octicon-comment:** (other comment)" popup-url="https://github.com/AY2223S2-CS2113-W13-1/tp/issues/150#issuecomment-1493257540" expanded>
